result.markdown:
--- title: "Loading and saving data in R" author: "Martin Schweinberger" date: "2022-08-31" --- ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](https://slcladal.github.io/images/uq1.jpg){width=100%} ::: ::: # Introduction{-} The data we work with comes in many formats and types. Therefore, this tutorial shows how you can load and save different types of data when working with R. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](https://slcladal.github.io/images/g_chili.jpg){width=15% style="float:right; padding:10px"} ::: ::: This tutorial is aimed at beginners with the aim of showcasing how to load and save different type of data and data structures in R. The aim is not to provide a fully-fledged analysis but rather to show and exemplify how to load and save various different types of data in R.

The entire R Notebook for the tutorial can be downloaded [**here**](https://slcladal.github.io/content/loading.Rmd). If you want to render the R Notebook on your machine, i.e. knitting the document to html or a pdf, you need to make sure that you have R and RStudio installed and you also need to download the [**bibliography file**](https://slcladal.github.io/content/bibliography.bib) and store it in the same folder where you store the Rmd file.


## Preparation and session set up{-} This tutorial is based on R. If you have not installed R or are new to it, you will find an introduction to and more information how to use R [here](https://slcladal.github.io/intror.html). For this tutorials, we need to install certain *packages* from an R *library* so that the scripts shown below are executed without errors. Before turning to the code below, please install the packages by running the code below this paragraph. If you have already installed the packages mentioned below, then you can skip ahead ignore this section. To install the necessary packages, simply run the following code - it may take some time (between 1 and 5 minutes to install all of the packages so you do not need to worry if it takes some time). ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # install packages install.packages("xlsx") install.packages("tidyverse") install.packages("flextable") install.packages("openxlsx") install.packages("here") # install klippy for copy-to-clipboard button in code chunks remotes::install_github("rlesur/klippy") ``` ::: Now that we have installed the packages, we can activate them as shown below. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # set options options(stringsAsFactors = F) # no automatic data transformation options("scipen" = 100, "digits" = 4) # suppress math annotation # load packages library(tidyverse) library(flextable) library(xlsx) library(openxlsx) library(here) # activate klippy for copy-to-clipboard button klippy::klippy() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html} ``` ::: ::: Once you have installed RStudio and initiated the session by executing the code shown above, you are good to go. # Excel data{-} There are several different functions that allow us to read Excel files into R. To load excel data from the web, you can use the `read.xlsx` function from the `openxlsx` package. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # load data excel <- openxlsx::read.xlsx("https://slcladal.github.io/data/testdata1.xlsx", sheet = 1) # inspect head(excel) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Variable1 Variable2 1 6 67 2 65 16 3 12 56 4 56 34 5 45 54 6 84 42 ``` ::: ::: To load excel data from your own computer, you can use the `read_excel` function from the `readxl` package (which is part of the tidyverse and thus does not need to be installed separately. ***

NOTE

You would need to adapt the path to the data (which currently points to the data folder on my computer!). Thus, the path below is specified to my computer.
`
` *** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # load data excel <- readxl::read_excel(here::here("data", "testdata1.xlsx"), sheet = 1) # inspect excel ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 10 Ã— 2 Variable1 Variable2 1 6 67 2 65 16 3 12 56 4 56 34 5 45 54 6 84 42 7 38 36 8 46 47 9 64 54 10 24 29 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ```{=html}
First 10 rows of the excelcomp data.

Variable1

Variable2

6

54

29

``` ::: ::: ## Write/Save Excel files{-} # txt-Files{-} ## Load txt with tabular data{-} If the data is tabular and stored as a txt-file, there are various functions to read in the data. The most common functions are `read.delim` and `read.table`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # load tab txt 1 tab1 <- read.delim("https://slcladal.github.io/data/mlrdata.txt", sep = "\t", header = TRUE) # inspect data head(tab1) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # load tab txt tab2 <- read.table("https://slcladal.github.io/data/mlrdata.txt", header = TRUE) # inspect head(tab2) ``` ::: # Text{-} # Read R (rda) Objects{-} In our case, we use the `readRDS` function which loads Rdata sets. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # load data with read.delim mytable <- base::readRDS(url("https://slcladal.github.io/data/mld.rda", "rb")) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ```{=html}
First 10 rows of mytable.

status

``` ::: ::: If the data is stored as a txt-file, there are various functions to read in the data. The most common functions are `read.delim` and `read.table`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # load data with read.delim tab1 <- read.delim("https://slcladal.github.io/data/mlrdata.txt", sep = "\t", header = TRUE) tab2 <- read.table("https://slcladal.github.io/data/mlrdata.txt", header = TRUE) ``` ::: # Citation & Session Info {-} Schweinberger, Martin. 2022. *Loading data into R*. Brisbane: The University of Queensland. url: https://slcladal.github.io/loading.html (Version 2022.08.31). ``` @manual{schweinberger2022tabr, author = {Schweinberger, Martin}, title = {Loading data into R}, note = {https://slcladal.github.io/loading.html}, year = {2022}, organization = "The University of Queensland, School of Languages and Cultures}, address = {Brisbane}, edition = {2022.08.31} } ``` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} sessionInfo() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` R version 4.2.1 (2022-06-23) Platform: x86_64-pc-linux-gnu (64-bit) Running under: Ubuntu 22.04.1 LTS
